column4: hi. in ubuntu hardy when i try to add a user to a group why can't i see www-data group?
probably because it's a system group
what's system group have to do with user joining it?
you are using the gui right?
yes i am using gui
I imagine it's an attempt to keep the interface simple.  User's shouldn't generally be part of system groups
well when i have set the user as a admin atleast i have to see the groups.
huh?
the user in the admin group. so he should atleast be able to see the system groups right?
shouldn't really matter.  If it's not showing them to you, it's because that's how the program is written.  It provides a checklist for some like (admin etc.)
but can I ask why you want the user to be in www-data?
if a developer wants to edit html files in /var/www i would prefer all the files are owned by www-data and the user be in www-data group.
that's really not best-practice, you want www-data to only be able to write where apache really *needs* to
i didn't get you. what do you mean by "write where apache really needs to"?
apache runs as www-data.  If you give www-data write permissions, then apache can write to the file

you should create some other group like "www-editors", add your users to that, and use that instead.  If you have a file that you need apache to be able to write to (e.g. a wiki), then let www-data have permission
ok so i would just put the files in /var/www give read permissions in /var/www add the user to www-data. is that fine? the user does dev of pages in his own directory.
yes i have a wiki too.
you're missing the point
you don't want apache to be able to write to randompage.html because there's no reason for it to ever do so
this is tangential to your original question
so i should be setting /var/www to www-editors group and www-data user?
no :/
